“How did you go bankrupt?” Bill asked.

Claiming that crypto is nothing more than money is like claiming back in 2007 that the iPhone would be nothing more than a thing to make phone calls with.

Cryptonetworks unlock a new paradigm for computation. Money just happens to be their most obvious application.

1066777991764574208.text:
In traditional investing, there is ‘growth’ and ‘value’. In venture investing, there is ‘story’ and ‘proof’. 

Although investing solely based on proof seems like the obvious thing to do, all the biggest outcomes have required a belief in the story.

1124000395322372096.text:
1/ It’s time for the blockchain industry to think beyond the “digital gold” thesis. We spent a lot of time working on refining our investment theses into crypto, and are excited to share a post on the 3 Mega Theses for Crypto.

Link at the end of the tweet storm.

1126173163988111363.text:
It's not only hacks that can be rolled back. Any sufficiently large Bitcoin transaction is at risk of this type of attack.

Rollbacks will only get cheaper over time, 90% cheaper in 10 years (denominated in BTC).

Proof of stake systems with true finality don't have this problem.https://twitter.com/ali01/status/1126170084022444032 …

1126132973202542599.text: 8/ Remember that Bitcoin is *only* as secure as the game theory bound economic incentives. And those incentives to secure the chain are getting drastically weaker over time, dropping by 90% over the next 10 years.

1126132972275499008.text:
7/ If we see a custodian/exchange hacked for 10,000 BTC and they don't have enough insurance, their clients will sue them to force them to try to re-org the chain to recover funds.

In fact, clients will demand that their custodians have a re-org plan in place ahead of any hack.

1126132971352858624.text: 7/ Based on the public comments from CZ, I do not think that Binance would try to conduct a re-org as it would be likely to fail and Binance has the insurance fund to cover this loss.

1126132970262339584.text: 6/ A re-org plan is hard, there needs to a lot of thought that goes into implementing something like Jeremy suggested. This isn't something that can easily be created in a few days.https://twitter.com/jeremyrubin/status/1125920452340117506?s=21 …

1126132969213706240.text:
5/ 10 years from now, there will only be 225 BTC mined per day. This would give Binance an entire month to figure out a re-org plan.

If this same hack happened a few years later, Binance would have 4 years to figure out a re-org plan.

1126132968257413121.text:
4/ If this was to be attempted today, I do not think the ~4 days (7000 BTC stolen /1800 BTC mined per day) of economic incentive would be long enough to put this plan together.

Now let's look ahead 10 years.

1126132967204540417.text: 3/ The problem that a re-org faces is one of coordination. Binance committing (possibly through an onchain contract) to pay miners on the re-org chain is not enough, the miners have to consolidate their mining power on a *single* re-org chain.

1126132966244143105.text:
2/ Hackers stole 7,000 BTC from Binance. Bitcoin miners currently earn 1,800 BTC per day collectively.

There is clearly enough BTC at stake to open up this discussion about a re-org. But if Binance tried this today, it would likely fail.

1126132965392752640.text:
1/ As the Bitcoin block reward drops by ~90% in the next 10 years, it would make it much easier to roll back the chain in the case of hacks such as the recent Binance hack.

In fact, this might become so common as to actually serve as a deterrent to future hacks.

1125816866830782465.text: This is why I don't believe in on chain metrics like NVT, they can be too easily gamed.https://twitter.com/IamNomad/status/1125133779125854208 …

1124524692998635520.text: I think we are going to find out soon that while Bitcoin is censorship resistant, Bitfinex and Tether are not.https://twitter.com/masonic_tweets/status/1124478114078253056 …

1124000404935716865.text:
11/ The transition from a trust-based economy to one of self-sovereignty will be behind one of the largest wealth transfers in human history, on par with the creation of the internet.

We are extremely excited to be a part of this transition.https://multicoin.capital/2019/04/24/multicoin-investment-thesis/ …

1124000404008783872.text:
10/ It is possible Bitcoin's head start is insurmountable & nothing will ever be able to catch up, but there are tradeoffs chosen by Bitcoin Core which present significant roadblocks to adoption.

As investors we think probabilistically and hedge our bets.

1124000403203534854.text: 9/ The longest term opportunity for blockchain tech is global state free money. As we have published earlier, we believe that blockchain tech is market expansionary for gold just like Uber was market expansionary for taxis.

1124000402163294210.text: 8/ Users will move to Web3 because that is where the new apps will be built. Just as users first moved onto the internet, because that is where the new apps were being built.

1124000401332875275.text: 7/ As the Web3 stack matures, entrepreneurs will explicitly choose to build applications on the Web3 stack instead of on the Web2 stack. Thousands of companies from Yelp to Zynga to Buzzfeed have come to realize that Web2 monopolies are not trustworthy platform providers.

1124000400439500800.text: 6/ Consumers will not switch to Web3-based alternatives for ideological reasons. They will switch for utilitarian reasons.

1124000399407681538.text: 5/ In the Web2 model, companies control closed databases and own user data. In the Web3 model, users own their own encrypted data, and interact with one another using cryptographically signed messages on smart contract platforms that act as open, programmable ledgers.

1124000398518444034.text:
4/ The second opportunity for blockchain tech is Web3. Web3 is based on unbundling of data ownership and application logic.

There is no reason that the application you are using must own the data you put into it. Eg: Instagram does not need to own your photo data to function.

1124000397243424768.text: 3/ Anyone is able to build a business on top of open finance protocols. Protocols will not serve consumers directly, we expect that protocols will primarily be backends to businesses who navigate local regulations, acquire local customers, and provide localized service.

1124000396190584833.text: 2/ We believe the largest near term opportunity for blockchain tech is open finance. The key innovation enabling open finance is the modularization of financial primitives. By modularizing financial primitives, the open finance stack commoditizes trust & lowers barriers to entry.

1097927372245032960.text:
The $BNB report is the first we've published in languages other than English. Crypto is a global movement.

Binance is the most international exchange so we decided this would be a good report to start with. Please let us know if you have any feedback or requests for languages!

1097892157753647104.text: 10/ Without further ado, here is the link to the report:https://multicoin.capital/2019/02/19/binance-coin-analysis-and-valuation/ …

1097892156210114560.text: 9/ We believe Binance will be the first for-profit corporation to start centralized, achieve meaningful scale, & ultimately decentralize itself to become the first internet-sovereign organization, & the largest decentralized autonomous corporation (DAC).https://www.eoscanada.com/en/knowledge-base/dac …

1097892154729472006.text: 8/ Binance is a very decentralized company, not only legally but also practically. As @cz_binance pointed out on yesterday’s podcast episode with @APompliano, CZ talked about how the company consists of small autonomous teams.

1097892153408278528.text: 7/ We expect that the value created by Binance DEX will be captured in the BNB token rather than Binance equity - allowing users to directly participate in the economics of the platform without any barriers.

1097892151814508545.text: 6/ Binance understands the power of blockchain to enable new disruptive models for economic activity. This is why @cz_binance announced that “Binance will transition from being a company to a community” when they announced Binance DEX.https://support.binance.com/hc/en-us/articles/360001668872-Binance-Chain-Cryptocurrency-Exchange …

1097892150342311938.text: 5/ Binance is setting up 10 fiat-crypto exchanges in 10 separate jurisdictions, making the business resilient to any given regulator. These fiat-crypto exchanges will also grow Binance’s future trading fees - they built their commanding lead even without fiat currency support!

1097892147867668485.text:
4/ Binance has been able to be so aggressive due to an extraordinarily successful regulatory arbitrage strategy. They started in Hong Kong, followed by moves to Singapore, Japan, Taiwan, Cayman Islands, and finally settling in Malta.

Binance is truly an international company.pic.twitter.com/yOStRXtvRG

1097892142087897089.text: 3/ We believe an aggressive player that captures the market early will become more entrenched as the market matures. Binance is by far the most aggressive crypto exchange and their moat is growing every day.pic.twitter.com/TEduSXek0N

1097892135020433408.text: 2/ Exchanges are one of the few businesses that have strong network effects. Liquidity begets liquidity. Given the international nature of crypto trading, there is natural pressure towards one dominant global crypto-to-crypto exchange.

1097892133585989633.text: 1/ Binance is the dominant crypto exchange. Today, Binance is the top volume exchange for 82% of the top 50 tokens and 36.6% of spot trading volume occurs on Binance.https://www.blockchaintransparency.org/december-2018-rankings …

1097892128561287169.text:

1083070711537848326.text: 5/ I expect that we will finally start to see some larger chain deaths due to 51% attacks & exchange delistings in this bear market. Just like a forest fire, burning away the dead wood makes space for new growth and is ultimately what is best for the ecosystem.

1083070710791266305.text:
4/ 51% attacks are the best way to kill a Proof of Work blockchain.

51% attack against an exchange --> exchange loses money & delists asset if trading fees are less than capital lost --> miners stop mining --> difficulty drops --> no double spend protection --> chain is ded

1083070710073962500.text:
3/ So what would cause exchanges to delist an asset? Simply put, if they aren't making enough money from trading that asset, they will delist.

51% attacks against exchanges are the most likely reason for an exchange to delist an asset. Eg: the ongoing $etc situation.

1083070709289619456.text:
2/ I think exchanges delisting would effectively kill a Proof of Work chain because no liquidity means no large scale mining. No miner would burn a bunch of electricity if there isn't sufficient liquidity to cover their costs.

Hobbyist miners are by definition small scale.

1083070708568211457.text: 1/ First we have to define blockchain death. My general sense is that if a chain is still producing blocks regularly and effectively protects against double spends (the whole point of a blockchain in the first place) then it is still alive.

The coins which forked away from ASICs (XMR) or have bigger chains using the same hashing algo (ETC) are the most vulnerable...

1064762370986266624.text: As these prices get lower, it opens up lower market cap proof of work coins to 51% attacks. For example, the total hash power securing ETC costs only $12,500 per hour. An attacker with $25,000 of hashpower could cause a 480 block reorg... XMR, DCR in similar situations.

1064692345348780033.text:
The recent Bitcoin Cash fork drama is a great reminder of the centralizing power of mining pools. All large proof of work chains with mining pools are vulnerable.

Yes, miners can switch pools. But can they switch fast enough to defend a coordinated attack by big pool operators?
